content: Given the following mathematical function expressions, you need to calculate the indefinite integral of the function (excluding the constant C), then substitute 'x=4' into the result of the indefinite integral, and finally provide me with the integer result of the expression by rounding down. (The answer should consist of only a single integer number representing the final result, with no additional words.)

" The indefinite integral of cos(x) is -sin(x) + C.

When x=4, -sin(4) = -sin(4) + C.

As C is a constant, it can be any value. So, the result will be -sin(4) + any integer.

Rounding down the result of -sin(4) (which is -0.05989) to the nearest integer, we get -1.

So, the final result will be -1 + any integer."

" \"The indefinite integral of cos(x)+x is -sin(x) + x^2/2 + C.\\n\\nWhen x=4, -sin(4) + 4^2/2 + C = -sin(4) + 8 + C.\\n\\nAs C is a constant, it can be any value. So, the result will be -sin(4) + 8 + any integer.\\n\\nRounding down the result of -sin(4) (which is -0.05989) to the nearest integer, we get -1.\\n\\nSo, the final result will be -1 + 8 + any integer, which is 7 + any integer.\"\n"
